#5 the tuscon roads are just super old(ish) and they're worn. If you have an alignment issue, I'd say watch out. But as long as you're going the AZ speed limit of 10-15 over the established speed or the regular speed limit, you should be fine.

1. Arizona has received a lot of moisture, but that's not really where Lake Mead gets its water from. Keep in mind most of Arizona is south of Lake Mead, so most of the water in Arizona flows downhill to the Pacific without touching Mead. 

2. The majority of the Colorado River basin has remained relatively dry; at least dry enough that Mead isn't acting like Roosevelt or other lakes in the state.

3. The reservoirs on the Colorado River system are quite vast. Other reservoirs may see significant fills while Mead, being low in that chain, may see hardly any gain. 

4. Although low, Mead is actually not the last stop on the Colorado River. Hydrologists have to make a choice to keep Lake Havasu and other reservoirs at certain levels as well. The reasons behind what gets raised and what gets lowered are complex with many stakeholders.

I've seen this question come up before so thought I'd try my best to outline just a few of the reasons Mead isn't acting like other reservoirs in the state.
